Comment: Although most adjectives follow the noun they modify, there are a few adjectives that always or often precede. See section 5.4.3 in Borsley et al. (2007) for more discussion.
Welsh is strongly head-initial, in the sense that heads precede their complements across all phrase types (Borsley et al. (2007, p.7).
Some adjectives have distinct morphological forms. When used attributively, the adjective agreement is optional and the general form may also be used (Borsley et al_2007, p. 178).
In predicative position, adjectives never agree in gender or number with their noun (Borsley et al_2007, p. 179).
